It astonishes me that it should be necessary to even ask this question, but some people seem to be as delusional/desperate on the issue today as they have been for the last 8+ years so...

Let's see, which Party was the President from which wrote, endorsed and signed the Don't ask Don't tell policy into Law? It was a democrat. And didn't that same Democratic President sign the Defense of Marriage Act? Sure it was. In fact it was the first black President. So the real question is, which Political Party gives more pro homosexual lip service to that community in order to garner its support? To that question, the answer is surely the Democrats. But that just stands to reason because we all know they will say what ever the group they are speaking to wants to hear in order to get their vote.
 
 The problem with that Party is that once they get the votes and the power, they do nothing to fulfill the campaign promises they made. For example, the Dems have controlled the House and the Senate for 2 years now, can you name any pro-homosexual legislation they have brought forth and passed? I can't think of any. But we all know that when they were running in their respective State races, they all spoke to their local homosexual groups and made promises that they haven't kept.
 
 Just like when Obama and Biden have spoken to homosexual groups they have sworn to support Gay marriage, yet in each of their debates they claimed they opposed redefining marriage to mean anything other than that of a man and a woman. That is a stance that directly opposes Gay Marriage, and that's because they were speaking to a larger group of heterosexuals which is the majority demographic in America.
 
 The point is, if you can't believe anything these propagators of cheap lip service say's, then why would you vote for them at all? Because surely they are lying to someone. Why would you possibly believe they would betray the larger voting block for your tiny, yet very loud minority? So delude yourself if you like, but there is a huge difference between saying they are pro-homosexual and actually being pro-homosexual. 
 
 When it comes to the American Left who have proven time and again that they have no moral center at all, what is funny is that you are gullible enough to believe anything that they say. emoticon_xgood

As truly frightening as it is to actually pen these words, I must confess that I am somewhat in agreement with Archie. (I think I just threw up in my mouth!) Of course he goes overboard and confuses facts, but I agree when he says that for the most part, Democrat support of gays is lip-service.
 
 I do not think that Dems are any worse or better than Repubs at pandering to their constituencies to get votes. And no party gets dibs on a "moral center". The GOP sucked up to conservative religious types when it was in vogue, but now that is waning as the fundamentalists seem to be dropping in the polls. 
 
 But Bill Clinton did not have to sign DOMA. Any veto would have surely been overridden, but he could have done nothing and let it become law without his approval. He screwed up with gays in the military and was stinging from that. By the way, only a single GOP rep voted no, though a handful of dem senators and reps did.
 
 Also, it is absurd that something as benign and truly fair as ENDA can't make it through Congress. The democrats are willing to support civil unions, which may be identical to marriage, but will not support gay marriage. This may seem paradoxical, but this is fully in line with the opinion polls. There is essentially no gay political clout. 
 
 Now, clearly any pro-gay legislation has more luck with the Dems that the GOP, but I do not think either party is a friend to gays.

 I seems to me your argument is that politics works this way and we should just sit back and wait until it's politically expedient to expect the ability to get married to whom we want, the ability to serve our country in the military without lying and to receive protection from being fired or being kicked out of our house because of something inherent in our nature. 
 
 I once was at a fund raising dinner for some state-wide gay organization many years ago. This was during the years of Oregon's ongoing battle with anti-gay ballot initiatives. I was sitting next to a state representative Elizabeth Furse, a democrat. She was darling of the gay community because she showed up for dinner there and said an occasional nice thing about homos. She had recently voted against some pro-gay legislation (or in favor of something anti-gay, I can't remember). I was sitting next to her and I had to ask her how she could vote that way and show up for this dinner. Her answer astonished me. She said the pro-gay position was so unpopular that she she could not vote that way or she would not be re-elected. If she was not in office she therefore could not help the gay community. I pointed out the only thing a legislator can do to help anyone is to pass legislation that is in his best interest. She went back to her grilled salmon. 
 
 My point is, with friends like this...
 
 Don't tell me you are a my friend and then not follow through with it with the only tool you have - changes to law and policy. For god's sake - we can't pass a pissant employment non-discrimation act! 
 
 Again, I grant you that Democrats are marginally better than Republicans. At least the dems don't have an anti-gay marriage amendment on the party platform.
 
 I am an independent. I mostly vote for democrats (and much moreso in the last several years) , but I do so on the issues, never because of the party.

I think that part of the problem gay Democrats have in dealing with their party -- there's no point in talking about gay Republicans!!! -- is that the gay liberation movement has never had a strong leadership the way the civil rights movement had. And many of the leaders who have emerged, seem to be party people first, and gay activists second.
 
 I don't really see a solution here. I think individual gay voters shouldn't shirk asking Democratic pols how they stand, but I wouldn't expect miracles from official gay activist organisations such as, say, HRC. They have divided loyalties.
 
 It is, needless to say, in the interest of our reflexive GOP supporters to magnify the dissensions among Democrats on gay rights, and so attempt to deflect attention from the extremely homophobic policies of the party they cherish. They like to ignore that voters rarely get the perfect candidates of their choice, but nothing would please supporters of the flagging McCain for Democrats to take umbrage because their candidates aren't perfect.
 
 The choice has always been stark for gay voters: voting Democrat has always been safer for gay rights than voting GOP. It shouldn't necessarily be that way, but ever since the GOP got hijacked by Christian fascists, or people who would callously use Christianism to gain power, it has been a clear danger to gay Americans.
 
 Voting Republican is usually dangerous for the health of gay people. It's a pity a quarter of gay voters never realised this the last two elections. Maybe they'll come to their senses in this one.

Anathema to the 75% of gay voters who vote Democrat, not because they particularly like the Democrats, but because they don't have any real choices, and the Dems are, at the very worst, not nearly as homophobic as the GOP.
 
 Actually, I don't think all GOP candidates are homophobic themselves... even the sleaziest candidates such as ex-senator Rick Santorum who never came across an anti-gay issue he didn't like, personally employed gay people among his staff. But they understand their religious constituency, and if throwing gay Americans to the wolves is what will get the GOP votes from the religious hooligans, that's what these people of alleged moral character will do.
 
 BTW, the 25% figure of gay GOP supporters comes from exit polls in the last two elections. What I really cannot figure out is why a gay man would want to work for someone like Santorum, who would happily deprive his gay staffers of their civil rights. My only conclusion is self-hatred or insanity.

What I really cannot figure out is why a gay man would want to work for someone like Santorum, who would happily deprive his gay staffers of their civil rights. My only conclusion is self-hatred or insanity.

 
 Probably because their world doesn't revolve around a single issue. For some, believe it or not, being gay or not really isn't the be-all-end-all issue; there are other issues that are also important--maybe even MORE important (if you can imagine that!). For example, gay rights doesn't do a whole lot of good if you aren't even around to have them because your right to defend yourself adequately was taken away by over-restrictive gun control.

Which party would be most likely to run an openly gay candidate for high office??? Dems, that's who. The Republicans could never get permission from Dr. Dobson and company to do so. 
 
 (Hiya, Lesz and Michael! :) Glad to see you guys still around. I was just thinking about CNN today and missing the old scene. Thought I'd stop in here and see if anybody needed my help in deciding how to vote in the election. ;) JLWest here, btw.)

And particularly if I had reason to doubt the sincerity of the candidate's party who professed to be for Christians since they had only done nominal things compared to what it COULD have done up to that point.

 Gay marriage and gays adopting is generally frowned upon by working class people, get over it. Dont pin it all onto Christians. If I was openly gay the people who I work and socialise with would treat me very differently( not that I am gay) than they do now.
 It's the way it is, sorry.
 If you want to know who calls Christianity an 'abomination or perversion' just look around this site!

Gay marriage and gays adopting is generally frowned upon by working class people, get over it. Dont pin it all onto Christians. 

 
 It's interesting you say that; the most anti-gay person I've ever known hates Christians too. They HATE minorities and also hate churches with a passion. This thing of associating hate with religion is really a relatively new concept--a line of attack, actually. It's rarely that way in real life. Most people who have a religious way of looking at gay-related issues aren't doing it out of hate and are often compassionate people. 
 
 Think about it--the only people who ever really make this sort of claim are gay rights advocates and people they've influenced. For heaven's sake, the civil rights movement for black people CAME OUT of religion! Religion was their salvation, in a sense. If religion was all about hate as some of them portray it as, the civil rights movement wouldn't have come out of churches.
 
 People really need to step back and think for themselves on issues like this.

 No, there's no reason to 'frown' upon gays. To frown upon them IS a form of hate--it's looking upon them negatively as people. Frankly, to change 'hate' to 'frown' is nothing more than a meaningless semantic distinction. Even if you do frown upon them, call it what it is. Don't sugarcoat it.

 We were talking about why some gay person would help Santorum get elected.
 Was Santorum running against the guy with "666" tattooed on his skull?
 No?
 
 Then kindly recognize that something significant was just explained to you about your presupposition, instead of coming up with fantasy hypotheticals to create scenarios where that would happen...
 
 
 
And particularly if I had reason to doubt the sincerity of the candidate's party who professed to be for Christians since they had only done nominal things compared to what it COULD have done up to that point.

 Um...
 To extend the analogy back to reality.
 
 Some people THINK that there have been "nominal" things done by the one party, but there HAVE BEEN things done by that party...
 While the OTHER PARTY ACTIVELY OPPOSES every move, and actually fought to try to make sure that the sex of Christians was illegal.
 
 But you go ahead and vote for the people who want to make sure you can't serve in the military, adopt, or even have sex, if that makes ya feel good! Work to get them elected so you can be discriminated against, cause you don't want to be seen as a "one issue voter"... emoticon_xgood

 But enduring governmentally legislated prejudice / discrimination? That's unacceptable.
 
 
 
No. To 'frown' upon them is to 'frown' upon them .
 To 'hate 'something or someone you would need to want to destroy them.

 Maybe I'm missing the point, but why does it matter?
 
 Suppose Jimmy destroys something, but he didn't "want" to do that.
 Perhaps he was misguided. Perhaps he was ignorant of his effects. Perhaps he was indifferent and pompous.
 
 In the end, that thing is still destroyed whether or not "hate" existed or not...

Way to ignore the point while coming up with a hypothetical scenario that I suspect has never actually existed in the U.S. ...

 
 Obviously the 25% felt it exists. Obviously the LCR feel it exists, or they wouldn't be there. Look, they are gay Republicans because of OTHER issues. There are more pressing things to be concerned about for the country.
 
 FWIW, I feel you are getting into a habit of quibbling with me over rather BASIC, OBVIOUS issues. Why else would Log Cabin Republicans EVEN EXIST other than the reasons I've given here?
 
 I just don't see how you could possibly be disagreeing on this--something so basic. The only conclusion I can come to is just pure beligerence on your part.

 The many non christian people that would feel like that would not need to be a part of any organisation to affect an election . Its called Democracy.
 Politicians will dupe the public, make promises and break them if they think it is worth it . The gay issue is only a live one because of the high profile support it has. Most people do not give the issue much thought, when asked say' live and let live' but would not approve of thier 18 year old son having sex with a 30 year old man but would probably not worry about the same son having sex with a 30 year old woman. As said thats the way it is ,get over it!
